TWA
TRANS WORLD AIRLINES
SCHEDULED
SKY COACH
SERVICE
We're happy to welcome you aboard your Slay
Coach! We believe you'll enjoy your flight, particu-
larly when you think of the appreciable saving that
Sky Coach travel means to you.
To make that saving possible, you'll notice we've
put in more seats than usual. And some of the lux-
urious features of TWA Skyliner service, such as
complimentary meals, free accommodations in the
event of delay enroute, more than one hostess to
each plane, family fares or round-trip discounts,
and a few other personal services are not included
in Sky Coach travel. It means greatly reduced fares,
advantagent mavel beople can now take the fullest
TWA Sky Coach travel means you're flying with
one of the largest regularly scheduled airlines in
the world, with more than twenty years of experi-
ence and a splendid record of performance and
dependability.
You can be sure that every care is
taken to maintain the highest performance stand-
ards for all Sky Coach flights.
There's a regular TWA flight crew up front in
your plane, with long experience flying the route
you're on right now. And ground maintenance and
flight control are of course as exacting as they are
for all
TWA's
and international
operations. Thats why TWA Sky Coachernatio na-
mous for dependable, speedy, convenient service.
This flight packet contains booklets and information
about TWA and flying in general which we hope
will be interesting to you. Please accept it with our
compliments.
TRANS WORLD AIRLINES
U.S. A. • EUROPE • AFRICA • ASIA

This flight packet contains booklets and information

TRANS WORLD AIRLINES
U.S. A. • EUROPE • AFRICA • ASIA

Twenty Years of
Research, Service,
Dependability...
TWA's History
When a group of already established airlines were merged in 1930 to
form TWA, airlines as we know them now were in their infancy. But
even then, TWA was more than just an operator of airplanes carrying
passengers across the United States. TWA management was already laying
plans for better planes, for more reliable instruments, for better weather
analysis, for better things for commercial aviation. They had started the
pioneering which has blazed a trail second to none in the airline industry.
The search for better aircraft bore fruit early. TWA engineers, in co-
operation with the Douglas Aircraft Corporation, evolved the design and
specifications which led first to the DC-1 and then to the DC-2 which was,
of course, the forerunner of the DC-3 and the Douglas Skymaster-today's
dependable "workhorses of the airways."
Recognizing the need for a faster, larger, more comfortable airplane
that could fly over the weather at high altitudes, TWA executives and
engineers helped develop the first 4-engine high-altitude plane used in
commercial service... the famous Boeing Stratoliner. But great as the
advance of the Stratoliner was, an even greater advance for aviation was
to follow... and again the result of bold vision by TWA men. In 1944, the
collective skill and talent of TWA and Lockheed technicians produced
the now-famous "Constellation"-the airplane which gave the public and
the world's airlines a brand new set of standards for fast, luxury air travel.
But TWA's present position of leadership in world aviation was built
on many, many factors beside aircraft design and development. In its
ceaseless search for comfort and dependability, TWA has developed new
instruments, new weather data, new maintenance skills...yes, even new
ways to cook foods. Here are just a few examples of TWA's aviation
pioneering.
TWA carried passengers entirely by air in scheduled service across
the U.S.A. before any other airline, and operated 4-engine land
planes over-ocean on regular schedules. It was TWA that first devel-
oped and used pressurized cabins for "over-weather" flying. De-icers,
automatic pilots, the use of wing flaps as "air brakes" and the use
of radar for a commercial airline were also pioneered by WA. As
part of TWA's careful flight planning, staff
meteorologists were
employed, a written flight plan was required for every flight, and
experienced pilots were used as Flight Dispatchers to handle flights
from ground control. TWA's foresight and planning, research and
engineering have always been directed toward bringing the traveling
public the finest, most modern equipment, offering the greatest
security and comfort to the passenger.
TWA
TRANS WORLD AIRLINES

Seat Belt Fastened?
Baby Traveling
With You?
The rules require using
your seat belt. The captain's
sign will tell you when. Fas-
ten your seat belt when the
sign flashes on above the
door in the front of the
plane; when it goes off, you
can loosen it.
Smoking?
Your hostess has a limited
supply of such baby items
as safety pins, diapers,
strained foods, which she
will be glad to provide on
request. She is not per-
mitted to mix formulas, but
will be glad to heat your
bottles at feeding time.
Ears Closed Up?
Not in or near the plane
when it's on the ground,
and not in the air when the
pilot's sign flashes "No
Smoking.
Otherwise,
smoke as much as you
please, using the ash trays
on the arm of your seat and
near the window. Only cig-
arettes, please.
Too Hot
or Too Cold?
As the plane varies altitude,
especially when getting
ready for a landing, the
pressure on your inner and
outer ears may become un-
equal. A healthy yawn will
often equalize the pressure
and clear your ears; chew-
ing gum is also a help.
Like to
Freshen Up?
In the rack overhead are
pillows and blankets which
your hostess will be glad to
hand you at any time, if you
need them. She also watches
the temperature and ven-
tilation very closely, but if
you should
be uncomfort-
able, just ring for her.
The Team on the Ground
Like an iceberg with nine-tenths of its bulk hidden beneath the water,
most of TWA's personnel are not seen by the flying public. In fact, for
every TWA crew member in the air, there are 9 TWA men and women
on the ground. They include maintenance mechanics, station mana-
gers, ground radio men, aeronautical engineers, radio engineers, mete-
orologists and many, many others. There are more than 2,800 highly
skilled TWA employees in maintenance alone.
These maintenance
people and other TWA personnel on the ground all over the world work
together like a smoothly-oiled machine with one common goal...to
speed you to your destination quickly, dependably and comfortably.
There are lavatory facilities
in the rear of the cabin, for
both men and women, com
plete with all the comforts
and conveniences of home.
Please, no smoking in the
lavatories at any time. This
is most important!

Constellation in Flight
757
Color-foto by Trans World Airlines

TWAS UNIVERSAL
AIR TRAVEL PLAN
Fly anywhere
in the world and
CHARGE IT!
TWA
TRANS WORLD AIRLINES

TIMETABLE SUPPLEMENT Effective June 15-June 30, 1952
TRANS WORLD
AIRLINES
U.S.A. • EUROPE • AFRICA • ASIA
TRANS WORLD AIRLINES
NOTICE: To satisfy the unusual demand for TWA services,
TWA will be adding new flights at 15-day intervals during
the summer months. After the effective period of this special
timetable supplement, please call your local travel agent or
your nearest TWA office for latest flight information, or ask
for a copy of the latest revised timetable supplement.
Consult any TWA agent or representative for current rates
and general information. We regret that we are unable to
publish all TWA flight information in a single folder during
this time of rapidly increasing schedules.

TWA
